ground_truth: Eddie takes his cue ball from the cashier's cage and heads for a table, and as he passes Charlie, he mimics the cashier wickedly. The two go to a table where Eddie selects a house cue, then rolls it over the table top to test the roll and seems pleased. He runs his hand over the green felt as if he were caressing it, and his last test is to sweep the cue ball into the corner pocket. Eddie takes some balls out of the return box and throws them on the table, but Big John and Preacher lean forward in their chairs to listen in. Big John, with a stubbly cigar between his fingers, drifts over to their table, and as he walks off, Eddie smiles at Charlie, saying, "Eight sharp." A departing customer holds the door for an incoming one: Minnesota Fats. Heads turn when he makes his punctual appearance, and Fats' clothes reflect his high station at Ames Pool Hall: a gray felt bowler hat, and an expensive, tailored overcoat, with a carnation in its lapel and two silk handkerchiefs peeking up from its breast pocket. He moves like a sultan through the room, past Big John whose eyes dip significantly, and over to the coat rack where Henry respectfully takes his coat and hat. The buzzard-like eyes of the cashier direct his gaze toward Eddie's table as Fats withdraws a cigarette from his gold case, then casually strolls toward Eddie's table standing apart and quietly observing the sharp, precise movements of his prospective opponent. Even though Ames is filled with players, there is little noise other than the clicking of pool balls. Fats and Eddie regard each other with amusement, sharing the private joke of pool hustlers, and at his command, Ames comes to life. Players drag their chairs across the floor and position them around the main table. Eddie, hand to his mouth, realizes that the big moment has arrived and beckons to Charlie for his leather cue case. The uniformed maids withdraw the cover off the green felt top, and Sausage, the racker, begins to bang the balls into the wooden racking triangle. Fats is in the washroom, scrubbing his hands and nails, while Eddie stands and screws together his inlaid, ivory-pointed cue as Fats dries his hands. He and Fats eye one another, and Henry helps Fats on with his coat. Fats carefully extends his palms so that Henry may sprinkle on some talcum powder. Sausage finishes racking, and they are ready to start. Fats, immaculate in jacket and tie, tosses a wad of bills -- his stake money -- onto the table, and Charlie does the same, counting the bills out one by one as Willie takes the money. Two balls are rolled to the end of the table, and Fats and Eddie, like two duelers, prepare to shoot for the break.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Eddie takes his cue sphere from the cashier's pen and heads for a table, and as he passes Charlie, he imitates the cashier mischievously. The two go to a table where Eddie selects a house cue, then rolls it over the table top to test the roll and seems satisfied. He runs his hand over the green baize as if he were stroking it, and his last test is to sweep the cue ball into the corner pocket. Eddie takes some balls out of the return container and throws them on the table, but Big John and Preacher lean forward in their seats to listen in. Big John, with a bristly stogie between his fingers, drifts over to their table, and as he walks off, Eddie smiles at Charlie, saying, "Eight sharp." A departing patron holds the door for an incoming one: Minnesota Fats. Heads turn when he makes his timely appearance, and Fats' attire reflects his high station at Ames Pool Hall: a gray felt bowler hat, and an expensive, tailored topcoat, with a carnation in its lapel and two silk handkerchiefs peeking up from its breast pocket. He moves like a sultan through the room, past Big John whose eyes dip significantly, and over to the coat rack where Henry respectfully takes his coat and hat. The buzzard-like eyes of the cashier direct his gaze toward Eddie's table as Fats withdraws a cigarette from his gold case, then casually strolls toward Eddie's table standing apart and quietly observing the sharp, precise motions of his prospective adversary. Even though Ames is filled with players, there is little noise other than the clicking of billiard balls. Fats and Eddie regard each other with amusement, sharing the private jest of pool hustlers, and at his command, Ames comes to life. Players drag their chairs across the floor and position them around the main table. Eddie, hand to his mouth, realizes that the big moment has arrived and beckons to Charlie for his leather cue case. The uniformed maids withdraw the cover off the green baize top, and Sausage, the racker, begins to bang the balls into the wooden racking triangle. Fats is in the washroom, cleaning his hands and nails, while Eddie stands and screws together his inlaid, ivory-pointed cue as Fats dries his hands. He and Fats eye one another, and Henry helps Fats on with his coat. Fats carefully extends his palms so that Henry may sprinkle on some talcum powder. Sausage finishes racking, and they are ready to start. Fats, immaculate in jacket and tie, tosses a wad of bills -- his stake funds -- onto the table, and Charlie does the same, counting the bills out one by one as Willie takes the cash. Two balls are rolled to the end of the table, and Fats and Eddie, like two duelists, prepare to shoot for the break.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The cue ball is taken by Eddie from the cashier's cage and a table is headed for by him, and as Charlie is passed by him, the cashier is mimicked wickedly. A table is approached by the two, where a house cue is selected by Eddie, then it is rolled over the table top by him to test the roll and he seems pleased. The green felt is run over by his hand as if it is being caressed by him, and the cue ball is swept into the corner pocket as his last test. Some balls are taken by Eddie out of the return box and he throws them on the table, but Big John and Preacher lean forward in their chairs to listen in. A stubbly cigar is held by Big John between his fingers, and their table is drifted over to by him, and as he walks off, Charlie is smiled at by Eddie, saying, "Eight sharp." The door is held by a departing customer for an incoming one: Minnesota Fats. Heads turn when his punctual appearance is made, and his high station at Ames Pool Hall is reflected by Fats' clothes: a gray felt bowler hat, and an expensive, tailored overcoat, with a carnation in its lapel and two silk handkerchiefs peeking up from its breast pocket. Like a sultan, he moves through the room, passing Big John whose eyes dip significantly, to the coat rack where his coat and hat are taken by Henry respectfully. The buzzard-like eyes of the cashier direct their gaze toward Eddie's table as a cigarette is withdrawn by Fats from his gold case, then Eddie's table is strolled toward casually, standing apart and quietly observing the sharp, precise movements of his prospective opponent. Even though the place is filled with players, there is little noise other than the clicking of pool balls. Amusement is shared between Fats and Eddie, the private joke of pool hustlers being shared by them, and at his command, Ames is brought to life. Chairs are dragged across the floor by players, and they position them around the main table. With hand to mouth, Eddie realizes that the big moment has arrived and calls Charlie for his leather cue case. The cover is withdrawn off the green felt top by the uniformed maids, and the balls are banged into the wooden racking triangle by Sausage, the racker. Washing his hands and nails, Fats is in the washroom while Eddie stands and screws together his inlaid, ivory-pointed cue as Fats dries his hands. One another is eyed by him and Fats, and with Fats' coat being helped on by Henry. Fats extends his palms carefully so that some talcum powder may be sprinkled on by Henry. The racking is finished by Sausage, and the start is ready for them. Immaculate in jacket and tie, Fats tosses a wad of bills -- his stake money -- onto the table, and the same is done by Charlie, counting the bills out one by one as the money is taken by Willie. To the end of the table, two balls are rolled, and to shoot for the break, Fats and Eddie, like two duelers, prepare.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Eddie grabs his cue ball from the cashier and heads to a table, wickedly imitating the cashier as he passes Charlie. He picks a house cue, checks its roll, and caresses the green felt. After testing the cue ball, he tosses balls onto the table. Big John, holding a stubbly cigar, leans in to listen, joining Preacher, while Eddie tells Charlie, "Eight sharp." As a customer exits, Minnesota Fats enters punctually, turning heads. His attire -- a gray felt bowler, an elegant coat with a carnation, and silk handkerchiefs -- reflects his status. Moving through Ames Pool Hall with authority, he gives his coat and hat to Henry. The cashier's eyes lead Fats to Eddie's table. With a cigarette from a gold case, he casually approaches, observing Eddie's sharp moves. Despite the crowd, only the click of pool balls is heard. Fats and Eddie exchange amused glances, understanding fellow hustlers. As Ames comes to life, players gather around the main table. Eddie signals Charlie for his cue case, and maids unveil the table. Sausage racks the balls, while Fats washes up. Eddie assembles his inlaid cue as Fats dries his hands and readies himself. Henry sprinkles talcum on Fats' palms before Sausage completes racking. Immaculately dressed, Fats throws a wad of bills on the table; Charlie matches the stake, and Willie collects the money. Fats and Eddie prepare to shoot for the break.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Eddie retrieves his cue ball from the cashier's cage, mimicking the cashier wickedly as he passes Charlie. At a table, Eddie selects a house cue, tests its roll, and sweeps the cue ball into a corner pocket. Big John, with a cigar, leans in from his chair, and as he walks away, Eddie smiles at Charlie, saying, "Eight sharp." Attention shifts to Minnesota Fats entering, clad in a bowler hat and tailored coat with a carnation and silk handkerchiefs. He moves through the room like a sultan, handing his coat and hat to Henry. The cashier's eyes guide him to Eddie's table, where Fats, cigarette in hand, observes Eddie. Although Ames is filled with players, noise is minimal. Fats and Eddie exchange amused glances, sharing the private joke of pool hustlers. Eddie beckons Charlie for his cue case as the room activates around the main table. Sausage racks the balls, and Fats washes and dries his hands as Eddie assembles his cue. Fats extends his hands for talcum powder, and they prepare to start. Fats, immaculate in jacket and tie, tosses his stake money onto the table, mirrored by Charlie. Fats and Eddie, like duelers, settle to shoot for the break.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Eddie, carrying his cue ball retrieved from the cashier’s cage, confidently makes his way over to a pool table. As he passes by Charlie, he playfully mimics the cashier’s expression in a wickedly entertaining manner. Together, Eddie and Charlie head towards a pool table where Eddie takes a moment to choose a house cue. After selecting one, he carefully rolls it over the table top to test its balance and precision, appearing quite pleased with its performance. Running his hand over the smooth green felt, as if caressing it lovingly, he conducts his final test by smoothly sweeping the cue ball into the corner pocket. 

Eddie then retrieves some balls from the return box and casually tosses them onto the felt-covered table. Meanwhile, Big John and Preacher, seated nearby, lean forward in their chairs, seemingly interested in what is unfolding. Big John, with a notably stubbly cigar nestled between his fingers, ambles over to join their table. As he meanders away, Eddie flashes a knowing smile at Charlie, confidently stating, "Eight sharp."

At that moment, a departing customer courteously holds the door open for another entering the establishment: the legendary Minnesota Fats. Heads naturally turn to observe his punctual entrance, and Fats’ attire unmistakably reflects his esteemed status at Ames Pool Hall. He sports a finely crafted gray felt bowler hat and dons an expensive, tailored overcoat adorned with a vibrant carnation in its lapel, complemented by two silk handkerchiefs dramatically peeking from the breast pocket. He traverses the room with the regal air of a sultan, moving past Big John, who respectfully lowers his eyes, heading directly to the coat rack where Henry dutifully takes his coat and hat.

The cashier, with a gaze like a watchful buzzard, directs his stare toward Eddie’s table as Fats nonchalantly extracts a cigarette from a gold case, then leisurely strolls over to Eddie’s table, choosing to stand apart and quietly assess the sharp, precise movements of his potential opponent. Though Ames is bustling with players, an almost hushed atmosphere prevails, broken only by the rhythmic clicking of pool balls. Fats and Eddie exchange amused looks, sharing a private, knowing smile familiar to pool hustlers, as Ames seems to awaken at Fats’ silent command. Players drag their chairs across the floor, arranging them strategically around the central table, where the action is about to unfold.

Eddie, with a hand raised thoughtfully to his mouth, acknowledges the significance of the moment with a subtle nod. He quietly signals to Charlie to bring over his finely crafted, leather cue case. Uniformed maids efficiently remove the protective cover from the green felt top, and Sausage, the racker, forcefully arranges the balls into the wooden racking triangle with loud, confident bangs. Meanwhile, Fats retreats to the washroom, where he diligently scrubs his hands and nails clean, emerging just as Eddie stands, assembling his inlaid, ivory-pointed cue. Fats dries his hands with care, and the two opponents exchange a meaningful glance, each recognizing the other’s skill. Henry gently assists Fats, aiding him in putting on his coat, before carefully sprinkling talcum powder onto Fats' outstretched palms.

With Sausage’s racking complete, the room is abuzz with anticipation as they prepare to commence. Fats, impeccably dressed in jacket and tie, nonchalantly tosses a wad of bills, representing his stake money, onto the table. In a similar fashion, Charlie follows suit, meticulously counting out the bills one by one, as Willie attentively gathers the money. Two balls are then rolled to the end of the table, and with the tension akin to that between two duelers, Fats and Eddie ready themselves to take the critical shot for the break, marking the beginning of an eagerly awaited match.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Eddie, holding the cue ball he had retrieved from the cashier’s cage with a sense of assurance, confidently makes his way over to one of the available pool tables in the busy establishment. As he passes by Charlie, he playfully mimics the cashier’s expression, doing so in a wickedly entertaining manner that amuses them both. Together, as a team, Eddie and Charlie proceed towards the chosen pool table, where Eddie pauses to thoughtfully select a house cue. After making his choice, he meticulously rolls it over the tabletop to test its balance and precision, appearing quite pleased and satisfied with its performance. Running his hand over the smooth green felt, as if caressing it lovingly, he conducts his final test by smoothly sweeping the cue ball into the corner pocket, demonstrating his ease and skill.

Eddie then moves to retrieve some balls from the return box, casually tossing them onto the felt-covered table. Meanwhile, Big John and Preacher, both seated nearby, lean forward in their chairs, seemingly intrigued by what is unfolding before them. Big John, notably clutching a stubbly cigar between his fingers, ambles over to join their table in a leisurely manner. As he meanders away, Eddie flashes a knowing smile at Charlie, confidently stating in a clear voice, "Eight sharp."

At that precise moment, a departing customer courteously holds the door open for another individual entering the establishment: the legendary Minnesota Fats. Heads naturally turn to observe his timely entrance, and Fats’ attire unmistakably reflects his highly esteemed status at Ames Pool Hall. He sports a finely crafted gray felt bowler hat and dons an expensive, tailored overcoat, adorned with a vibrant carnation in its lapel. The ensemble is complemented by two silk handkerchiefs dramatically peeking from his breast pocket. He traverses the room with the regal air of a sultan, moving past Big John, who respectfully lowers his eyes as a gesture of deference, and heads directly to the coat rack where Henry dutifully takes his coat and hat without hesitation.

The cashier, with a gaze as watchful as a buzzard’s, directs his stare and attention toward Eddie’s table as Fats nonchalantly extracts a cigarette from his gold case. He then leisurely strolls over to Eddie’s table, choosing to stand apart and quietly assess the sharp, precise movements of his potential opponent. Although Ames is bustling with players, an almost hushed atmosphere prevails, broken only by the rhythmic clicking of pool balls. Fats and Eddie exchange amused looks, sharing a private, knowing smile familiar to seasoned pool hustlers, as Ames seems to awaken at Fats’ silent command. Players drag their chairs across the floor, arranging them strategically around the central table, where the action is anticipated to unfold.

Eddie, with a hand raised thoughtfully to his mouth, acknowledges the significance of the moment with a subtle yet meaningful nod. He quietly signals to Charlie to bring over his finely crafted, leather cue case. Uniformed maids efficiently remove the protective cover from the green felt top with practiced ease, and Sausage, the diligent racker, forcefully arranges the balls within the wooden racking triangle with loud, confident bangs. Meanwhile, Fats retreats to the washroom, where he diligently scrubs his hands and nails clean, emerging just as Eddie stands, assembling his intricately inlaid, ivory-pointed cue. Fats dries his hands with meticulous care, and the two opponents exchange a meaningful glance, each recognizing the other’s well-regarded skill. Henry gently assists Fats, aiding him in putting on his coat, before carefully sprinkling talcum powder onto Fats' outstretched palms.

With Sausage’s racking complete, the room is abuzz with excitement and anticipation as they prepare to commence the game. Fats, impeccably dressed in his jacket and tie, nonchalantly tosses a wad of bills onto the table, representing his stake money. In a similar fashion, Charlie follows suit, meticulously counting out the bills one by one, as Willie attentively gathers the money with care. Two balls are then rolled to the end of the table, and with the tension akin to that between two duelers readying for a duel, Fats and Eddie prepare themselves to take the critical shot for the break, marking the beginning of an eagerly awaited and much-anticipated match.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Eddie approaches the cashier's cage, retrieves his cue ball with a focused demeanor, and strides purposefully toward a table. As he passes by Charlie, he takes a moment to mock the cashier with a mischievous gesture, delighting in the shared humor. Arriving at their chosen table, Eddie carefully selects a house cue, methodically rolling it across the tabletop to assess its balance and rolling quality, nodding with satisfaction at the results. He tenderly glides his hand over the smooth, green felt, indulging in the tactile sensation as if it were a personal ritual. For his final test, he confidently propels the cue ball into the corner pocket, observing its smooth trajectory. Eddie proceeds to fetch a set of balls from the return box and casually tosses them onto the table's surface, their clattering sound attracting the attention of Big John and Preacher, who lean forward with keen interest. Big John, gripping a stubbly cigar between his fingers, drifts over to their table with the leisurely pace of a man accustomed to the environment. As Big John saunters away, Eddie exchanges a knowing smile with Charlie, stating decisively, "Eight sharp." Meanwhile, as a departing customer holds the door open, the renowned Minnesota Fats makes his entrance with impeccable timing. His arrival commands attention, as heads turn to acknowledge his presence, and his attire—a gray felt bowler hat, a luxurious tailored overcoat adorned with a carnation, and silk handkerchiefs elegantly arranged in the breast pocket—speaks to his distinguished status at Ames Pool Hall. Moving with the regal bearing of royalty, Fats passes Big John, who acknowledges him with a deferential nod, and heads to the coat rack where Henry dutifully receives his coat and hat. The cashier, with sharp, watchful eyes, directs his gaze towards Eddie's table, while Fats, with a practiced nonchalance, withdraws a cigarette from a gold case and casually approaches Eddie's table, maintaining a strategic distance as he keenly observes Eddie's precise, deliberate actions. Despite the hall being filled with players, only the rhythmic clicking of pool balls punctuates the air. Fats and Eddie exchange amused glances, sharing an unspoken camaraderie familiar to seasoned pool hustlers, and at this unspoken signal, Ames Pool Hall springs to life. Enthusiastic players scrape their chairs across the floor, forming a semicircle around the main table in anticipation. Eddie, with a contemplative gesture of hand to mouth, acknowledges the gravity of the moment and signals to Charlie to bring his leather cue case. The uniformed maids efficiently remove the cover from the table's green felt top, while Sausage, the racker, vigorously stacks the balls within the wooden triangle, the sound echoing through the room. Meanwhile, Fats makes his way to the washroom, meticulously scrubbing his hands and nails with the precision of a craftsman, while Eddie stands firm, assembling the sections of his inlaid, ivory-pointed cue with calm determination as Fats dries his hands. As their eyes meet once more, Henry steps forward to assist Fats with his coat, applying talcum powder to Fats' outstretched palms with a practiced hand. With Sausage's task complete, the table is set, and the atmosphere crackles with anticipation. Fats, immaculate in his jacket and tie, confidently hurls a wad of bills—his stake—onto the table. Charlie follows suit, meticulously counting the bills one by one as Willie handles the money with poised efficiency. Two balls are sent rolling to the end of the table, the movement loaded with meaning as Fats and Eddie, poised like duelers, ready themselves to shoot for the break, setting the stage for the contest about to unfold.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Eddie retrieves his cue ball from the cashier's cage, mimics the cashier to entertain Charlie, and heads to a pool table. He selects and tests a house cue, running his hand over the felt and sweeping the cue ball into a pocket to finalize his choice. As he gathers balls from the return box, Big John and Preacher listen in, intrigued. Big John wanders over, cigar in hand, and Eddie exchanges a knowing smile with Charlie, signaling "Eight sharp." A departing customer holds the door for the incoming Minnesota Fats, whose arrival turns heads. Fats, dressed in a gray felt bowler, tailored overcoat with a carnation, and silk handkerchiefs, moves through Ames Pool Hall with a commanding presence. He hands his coat and hat to Henry, then observes Eddie's table while lighting a cigarette. Despite the room being filled with players, a hush hangs over it, broken only by the sound of pool balls. Eddie and Fats exchange amused glances, understanding the hustler's game. On Fats' command, the room comes alive as players reposition their chairs around the main table. Eddie signals Charlie for his cue case, and the green felt top is unveiled by uniformed maids. Sausage racks the balls, preparing for the match. Meanwhile, Fats washes his hands meticulously, and Eddie assembles his ivory-pointed cue. They eye each other as Henry assists Fats with his coat and sprinkles talcum powder on his hands. Sausage completes the rack, and both players, immaculate and ready, toss their stake money onto the table. Willie counts the money, and with two balls rolled to the end, Fats and Eddie prepare for the break, like duelers set for a showdown.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Eddie, after retrieving his personalized cue ball from the cashier's cage that serves as a hub for serious players, heads for a table, and as he passes Charlie, he wickedly mimics the cashier, known for his gruff demeanor. The two friends go to a table where Eddie selects a house cue, specifically chosen from Ames Pool Hall’s collection known for its high-quality cues, and rolls it over the table top to test the roll, a ritual among seasoned players, and seems pleased. He runs his hand over the green felt, a surface meticulously maintained, as if he were caressing it, and his last test is to sweep the cue ball into the corner pocket, ensuring its smooth movement. Eddie takes some balls out of the return box and throws them on the table, but Big John, whose reputation for gambling is widely recognized, and Preacher, so named for his habit of quoting scriptures, lean forward in their chairs to listen in. Big John, with a stubbly cigar between his fingers, a trademark of his, drifts over to their table, and as he walks off, Eddie smiles at Charlie, saying, "Eight sharp," referring to the time for their anticipated match. A departing customer holds the door for an incoming one: Minnesota Fats, a legendary figure in the world of pool, known for his impressive skills and larger-than-life personality. Heads turn when he makes his punctual appearance, and Fats' clothes reflect his high station at Ames Pool Hall, a venue famous nationwide for hosting top-tier pool talent: a gray felt bowler hat, and an expensive, tailored overcoat with a carnation in its lapel and two silk handkerchiefs peeking up from its breast pocket. He moves like a sultan through the room, past Big John whose eyes dip significantly, a quiet acknowledgment of Fats' status, and over to the coat rack where Henry, the attentive attendant, respectfully takes his coat and hat. The buzzard-like eyes of the cashier, always keen to spot talent, direct his gaze toward Eddie's table as Fats withdraws a cigarette from his gold case, a symbol of his affluence, then casually strolls toward Eddie's table standing apart and quietly observing the sharp, precise movements of his prospective opponent. Even though Ames is filled with players, many of whom aspire to challenge the best, there is little noise other than the clicking of pool balls. Fats and Eddie regard each other with amusement, sharing the private joke of pool hustlers, and at his command, Ames comes to life. Players drag their chairs across the floor and position them around the main table, eager to witness the match. Eddie, hand to his mouth, realizes that the big moment has arrived and beckons to Charlie for his leather cue case, a prized possession among players. The uniformed maids, part of the hall's traditional service staff, withdraw the cover off the green felt top, and Sausage, the racker known for his precise setups, begins to bang the balls into the wooden racking triangle. Fats is in the washroom, scrubbing his hands and nails, a pre-game ritual for good luck, while Eddie stands and screws together his inlaid, ivory-pointed cue, a custom-made tool of his trade, as Fats dries his hands. He and Fats eye one another, and Henry helps Fats on with his coat. Fats carefully extends his palms so that Henry may sprinkle on some talcum powder, ensuring a smooth grip on the cue. Sausage finishes racking, and they are ready to start. Fats, immaculate in jacket and tie, tosses a wad of bills -- his stake money -- onto the table, and Charlie does the same, counting the bills out one by one as Willie, the house's trusted money handler, takes the money. Two balls are rolled to the end of the table, and Fats and Eddie, like two duelers preparing for an epic showdown, prepare to shoot for the break.

Big John with a stubbly cigar between his fingers drifts over to their table and as he walks off Eddie smiles at Charlie saying. Eight sharp. A departing customer holds the door for an incoming one. Minnesota Fats. Heads turn when he makes his punctual appearance and Fats' clothes reflect his high station at Ames Pool Hall. a gray felt bowler hat and an expensive tailored overcoat with a carnation in its lapel and two silk handkerchiefs peeking up from its breast pocket. He moves like a sultan through the room past Big John whose eyes dip significantly and over to the coat rack where Henry respectfully takes his coat and hat. The buzzardlike eyes of the cashier direct his gaze toward Eddie's table as Fats withdraws a cigarette from his gold case then casually strolls toward Eddie's table standing apart and quietly observing the sharp precise movements of his prospective opponent. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. Even though Ames is filled with players there is little noise other than the clicking of pool balls. Fats and Eddie regard each other with amusement sharing the private joke of pool hustlers and at his command Ames comes to life. Players drag their chairs across the floor and position them around the main table. Eddie hand to his mouth realizes that the big moment has arrived and beckons to Charlie for his leather cue case. The uniformed maids withdraw the cover off the green felt top and Sausage. the racker begins to bang the balls into the wooden racking triangle. Fats is in the washroom scrubbing his hands and nails while Eddie stands and screws together his inlaid ivorypointed cue as Fats dries his hands. He and Fats eye one another and Henry helps Fats on with his coat. Fats carefully extends his palms so that Henry may sprinkle on some talcum powder. Sausage finishes racking and they are ready to start. Fats immaculate in jacket and tie tosses a wad of bills. his stake money  onto the table and Charlie does the same counting the bills out one by one as Willie takes the money. Two balls are rolled to the end of the table and Fats and Eddie like two duelers prepare to shoot for the break.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Eddie takes his cue ball from the cashier's cage and heads for a table and as he passes Charlie he mimics the cashier wickedly. The two go to a table where Eddie selects a house cue then rolls it over the table top to test the roll and seems pleased. He runs his hand over the green felt as if he were caressing it and his last test is to sweep the cue ball into the corner pocket. Eddie takes some balls out of the return box and throws them on the table but Big John and Preacher lean forward in their chairs to listen in. Big John with a stubbly cigar between his fingers drifts over to their table and as he walks off Eddie smiles at Charlie saying. Eight sharp. Fats is in the washroom scrubbing his hands and nails while Eddie stands and screws together his inlaid ivorypointed cue as Fats dries his hands. He and Fats eye one another and Henry helps Fats on with his coat. Fats carefully extends his palms so that Henry may sprinkle on some talcum powder. Sausage finishes racking and they are ready to start. Fats immaculate in jacket and tie tosses a wad of bills. his stake money  onto the table and Charlie does the same counting the bills out one by one as Willie takes the money. Two balls are rolled to the end of the table and Fats and Eddie like two duelers prepare to shoot for the break.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Eddie takes his cue ball from the cashier's cage and heads for a table and as he passes Charlie he mimics the cashier wickedly. The two go to a table where Eddie selects a house cue then rolls it over the table top to test the roll and seems pleased. Fats immaculate in jacket and tie tosses a wad of bills. his stake money  onto the table and Charlie does the same counting the bills out one by one as Willie takes the money. Two balls are rolled to the end of the table and Fats and Eddie like two duelers prepare to shoot for the break.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Lola grabs her banana from the librarian's nook and saunters to a bench, and as she approaches Jessie, she parodies the librarian mischievously. The duo moves to a bench where Lola picks a rental brush, then skates it over the bench surface to gauge the glide and seems content. She pats her hand over the blue silk as if she were fondling it, and her final test is to flick the banana into the flower pot. Lola pulls some apples out of the paper bag and tosses them on the bench, but Tall Sam and Pastor lean backward in their stools to eavesdrop. Tall Sam, with a dusty lollipop between his toes, ambles over to their bench, and as he hops away, Lola grins at Jessie, saying, "Nine crisp." An exiting dancer holds the gate for an incoming one: Nevada Slim. Hats swivel when he makes his timely arrival, and Slim's attire signals his lofty rank at Bitsy Bookshop: a violet velvet beret, and a lavish, custom-made cloak, with a lily in its buttonhole and three satin scarves peeking out from its sleeve pocket. He glides like a monarch through the library, past Tall Sam whose nostrils flare dramatically, and over to the boot rack where Harry courteously accepts his boots and beret. The hawk-like gaze of the librarian directs her vision toward Lola's bench as Slim extracts a lollipop from his brass container, then nonchalantly wanders toward Lola's bench standing aloof and silently inspecting the brisk, flawless gestures of his future contender. Even though Bitsy is brimming with readers, there is minimal sound beyond the rustling of pages. Slim and Lola assess each other with humor, sharing the obscure jest of bookworms, and at his signal, Bitsy springs to life. Readers drag their stools across the rug and arrange them around the key bench. Lola, hand to her ear, acknowledges that the crucial event has arrived and gestures to Jessie for her suede brush case. The costumed chefs remove the wrapper off the blue silk surface, and Noodle, the stacker, starts to clatter the apples into the plastic stacking prism. Slim is in the shower room, scrubbing his elbows and toes, while Lola leans and assembles her carved, bone-tipped brush as Slim wipes his elbows. She and Slim watch one another, and Harry assists Slim with his cloak. Slim tenderly unfolds his fingers so that Harry may sprinkle on some aloe lotion. Noodle finishes stacking, and they are set to commence. Slim, pristine in blazer and scarf, flings a bundle of pebbles -- his stake stones -- onto the bench, and Jessie does the same, counting the stones out one by one as Sammy takes the pebbles. Two apples are rolled to the end of the bench, and Slim and Lola, like two challengers, get ready to flick for the start.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Eddie takes his cue ball and heads to a pool table, playfully mimicking the cashier. He selects a house cue, tests it, and is satisfied. After setting up, Eddie throws the balls onto the table as Big John and Preacher watch closely. Eddie signals to Charlie, "Eight sharp," just as Minnesota Fats enters, turning heads with his impeccable attire, including a gray bowler hat and tailored overcoat. Fats moves confidently, handing his coat to Henry. With a gold cigarette case in hand, Fats notices Eddie. Despite the crowded Ames Pool Hall, the atmosphere is quiet, save for the clicking of pool balls. They share a mutual understanding as pool hustlers, and the room shifts focus to their impending match. Eddie calls for his cue case, and the table is prepared. Fats washes up and sprinkles talcum powder on his hands before stepping up to the table. Both players toss their stake money onto the table, roll balls to decide the break, and prepare to begin their tense duel.
